contentrichtext.text: [[File:XM395 Precision Guided Mortar Munition.jpg|thumb|300px|XM395 Precision Guided Mortar Munition prototype at Fort Benning, Ga., Feb 2006 <ref>[http://www.pica.army.mil/voice2006/060428/060428%20XM395.htm PM Mortar Systems demonstrates XM395 during exercise]</ref>]] The '''XM395 Precision Guided Mortar Munition''' (PGMM) is a 120 mm [[Precision-guided munition|guided]] [[Mortar (weapon)|mortar]] round under development by [[Alliant Techsystems]].<ref name="DID">[http://www.defenseindustrydaily.com/2004/12/alliant-techsystems-takes-army-mortar-contract-again/index.php Alliant Techsystems Takes Army Mortar Contract (Again)]</ref> ==Design== The mortar round has no moving parts and maneuvers itself to the target by means of embedded thruster motors.<ref name="AFI">[http://www.armedforces-int.com/categories/precision-guided-mortar-munition/precision-guided-mortar-munition.asp Armed Forces International]</ref> The guidance system shares the same Distributed Aperture Semi-Active Laser Seeker (DASALS) technology as the [[BAE Systems]] [[Advanced Precision Kill Weapon System|APKWS II]] rocket system.<ref>[http://www.baesystems.com/newsroom/2006/apr/110406news3.htm BAE SYSTEMS APKWS II OFFERING COMPLETES ENVIRONMENTAL TESTS]</ref> The most recent XM395 munition consist of a GPS-guided kit fitted to standard 120 mm smooth bore mortar rounds, that includes the fitting of a nose and tail subsystem containing the maneuvering parts.<ref>{{cite web|last=Calloway|first=Audra|title=Picatinny fields first precision-guided mortars to troops in Afghanistan|url=http://www.army.mil/article/53988/|work=Picatinny Public Affairs|publisher=US Army - Picatinny Arsenal|accessdate=21 February 2012|date=29 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=XM395: 120mm Precision Mortar|url=http://www.atk.com/ts/singaporeairshow/PDF/datasheets/108747_01_XM395%20ds.pdf|work=ATK Advanced Weapon|publisher=ATK|accessdate=21 February 2012}}</ref> ==Specification== * Caliber: 120 mm * Range: > 7 km<ref name="AFI"/> * [[Circular error probable|CEP]]: 1 m ==Program status== * December 2004: Alliant Techsystems regains an $80 million contract from the U.S. Army to begin production on the XM395 precision-guided mortar munition after a protest by [[Lockheed Martin]] a year previously.<ref name="DID"/> * January 2006: Successfully completed the preliminary design review (PDR) stage.<ref>[http://atk.mediaroom.com/index.php?s=press_releases&item=405 ATK Successfully Completes Preliminary Design Review of Precision Guided Mortar Munition]</ref> * February 2006: Successful ballistic flight test at [[Yuma Proving Grounds]].<ref>[http://atk.mediaroom.com/index.php?s=press_releases&item=395 ATK Conducts Successful Ballistic Flight Test of the Precision Guided Mortar Munition]</ref> * February 2007: Funding for program withdrawn in proposed FY2008 budget.<ref>[http://www.military.com/features/0,15240,120100,00.html Army Proposes Major Weapons Cuts - military.com]</ref> * March 2007: Successful guided flight test.<ref>[http://www.spacewar.com/reports/ATK_Precision_Guided_Mortar_Munition_Scores_Direct_Hit_In_Guided_Flight_Test_999.html ATK Precision Guided Mortar Munition Scores Direct Hit In Guided Flight Test]</ref> * April 2010: ATK's XM395 wins the U.S. Army's competition for the preferred mortar guidance kit.<ref>{{cite web|last=Brannen|first=Kate|title=ATK Wins U.S. Army Precision Mortar Contract|url=http://www.defensenews.com/article/20100421/DEFSECT02/4210310/ATK-Wins-U-S-Army-Precision-Mortar-Contract|publisher=Defense News|accessdate=21 February 2012|date=21 April 2010}}</ref> * March 2011: XM395 munition kit makes its combat debut in Afghanistan.<ref>{{cite web|last=Calloway|first=Audra|title=Picatinny fields first precision-guided mortars to troops in Afghanistan|url=http://www.army.mil/article/53988/|work=Picatinny Public Affairs|publisher=US Army -
